analyses.value:
We will first use a multilevel model regression with random effects for respondents to test the following model:

β1 MatchedParty + β2 MatchedParty*IssuePresent + β3 IssuePresent

MatchedParty is an indicator for whether the participant and the vignette subject have the same party affiliation. IssuePresent is an indicator for whether an issue preference is included in the vignette. Each issue will be analyzed in isolation and together with other issues. All models will be run twice: once excluding participants who saw a vignette issue as well as Republicans and Democrats' positions on the vignette issue, and once excluding participants who saw a vignette issue but not Republicans and Democrats' positions on the vignette issue.

## Individual Issue
model_1A <- lmer(therm ~ match_party*issue_pres + (1|workerId), data = models_df %>%
                 filter((vig_issue == 'data_sale' | is.na(vig_issue)) &
                          (partyPositions == 'no' | is.na(partyPositions))))
model_1A %>% summary()

model_1B <- lmer(therm ~ match_party*issue_pres + (1|workerId), data = models_df %>%
                 filter((vig_issue == 'data_sale' | is.na(vig_issue)) &
                          (partyPositions == 'yes' | is.na(partyPositions))))
model_1B %>% summary()

## Novel Issues
model_2A <- lmer(therm ~ match_party*issue_pres + (1|workerId), data = models_df %>%
                 filter(partyPositions == 'no' | is.na(partyPositions)))
model_2A %>% summary()

model_2B <- lmer(therm ~ match_party*issue_pres + (1|workerId), data = models_df %>%
                 filter(partyPositions == 'yes' | is.na(partyPositions)))
model_2B %>% summary()

– – –

We will then use a multilevel model regression with random effects for respondents to test the following model:

β1 MatchedParty + β2 MatchedParty*PartyPositions + β3 PartyPositions

MatchedParty is an indicator for whether the participant and the vignette subject have the same party affiliation. PartyPositions is an indicator for whether Republicans and Democrats' positions on the vignette issue were given prior to the vignette. Each issue will be analyzed in isolation and together with other issues. All participants who did not see a vignette issue will be excluded from this analysis.

## Individual Issue
model_1C <- lmer(therm ~ match_party*party_pos + (1|workerId), data = models_df %>%
                  filter(vig_issue == 'data_sale'))
model_1C %>% summary()

## Novel Issues
model_2C <- lmer(therm ~ match_party*party_pos + (1|workerId), data = models_df %>%
                   filter(!is.na(partyPositions)))
model_2C %>% summary()

outliers.value: Participants who identify as political Independents (i.e., do not lean toward the Republican Party or Democratic Party) will be excluded from our analysis.

dependent.value: Our key dependent variable, partisan animosity, will be operationalized by a feeling thermometer. This will be used to gauge a general sense of warmth/coolness toward individuals described in personal vignettes.

conditions.value:
Participants will be assigned to view two personal vignettes in eight conditions, each of which will be defined by three factors: types of information given in the vignette (party affiliation only / party affiliation and issue preference), party affiliation of vignette subject (Republican / Democrat), and whether Republicans and Democrats' positions on the vignette issue—randomized—were given before the vignette (yes / no).

In conditions where information about both party affiliation and issue preferences is present, the order of these details will be randomized per participant. Two other factors will remain constant across the two vignettes the participant reads: (1) types of information given in the vignette and (2) whether Republicans and Democrats' positions on the vignette issue were previously given.

hypothesis.value: How do party affiliation and policy preferences affect partisan animosity, when each is presented (1) in isolation or (2) together with the other?

attributes.title: Remotely sensed hyper-spectral signatures as indicators of biodiversity

q1.value: Can spectral data capture Arctic plant biodiversity?

q3.value:
Changes in plant communities are one of the most distinct responses to global climate change, yet we lack quantification of plant diversity and composition in the biome experiencing the highest rate of warming – the Arctic. Traditional methods of measuring biodiversity involve field studies and visual surveys, which are both resource intensive and limited in their spatial and temporal resolution. The synthesis of remotely sensed earth observation data with local climatic and topographical conditions, presents itself as a potential cost-effective and standardized technique to monitor biodiversity on an ecosystem wide scale. While high-resolution spectral data are becoming increasingly available at multiple scales, there is little known about the drivers of spectral diversity when transitioning from species to community-specific spectral data, particularly in tundra biomes. 
My goal is to evaluate the capabilities of using plot scale and remotely sensed spectral data to assess ecological traits. Understanding how environmental factors correspond with spectral diversity have implications for the feasibility of using hyperspectral data for remote biodiversity estimation. 

Purpose of study:
This will encompass using spectral signatures for the identification of Arctic vegetation type, as well as quantifying influencers of spectral diversity. Specifically, species richness, species evenness, and exposed soil will be investigated, as these factors contribute to spectral diversity in complex ways. 

Research questions 

1: Can Arctic Vegetation types be identified based on the mean and variance of hyperspectral signatures? 

2: How does spectral diversity relate to species richness, evenness, canopy cover, and soil-background?

3: What parts of the full spectrum best discriminate vegetation types? 

4: Are closer measurements more similar than more distant measurements? 

5: Do plot and airborne spectra differ?  Do plot or airborne spectra show more variation among vegetation types?

6: Can airborne remotely-sensed spectral diversity be used to identify vegetation types at the island scale?

q4.value:
1: How do Arctic Vegetation types be discriminate based on the mean and variance of hyperspectral signatures?

H1: Arctic vegetation types can be identified based on the mean of their spectral signature (H1a) and spectral variance of their spectral signature (H1b). Spectral variance will have a larger correspondence with vegetation type (H1c).  When ordinated, spectral signatures will discriminate among vegetation types (H1d) and year of measurement (corresponds with change in sensor type) (H1e).

H1o: Arctic vegetation types do not differ based on the mean or variance of their spectral signatures, and do not discriminate when ordinated. 

Predicted results 

I predict that both the mean and variance of spectral signatures can be used to identify Arctic vegetation types. The diversity of a spectral signature correlates with the chemical, anatomical, and morphological traits of communities (Schweiger et al., 2017).   Given the compositional difference between communities, this should translate into observable differences in spectral signatures. 

I predict that spectral variance will have higher correspondence with vegetation types, as it captures the spectral complexity within each vegetation type (Wang et al., 2018). If spectral variance has a higher correspondence with vegetation types, this  means that the vegetation types discriminate based on overall spectral diversity, which is variable at all spectral regions and is influenced by compositional differences, such as biological, functional, and phylogenetic diversity. 

If the mean of spectral signatures has greater correspondence with vegetation type, this indicates that the spectral complexity of a vegetation type is less important than between-type differences in spectral signatures. These differences would relate to course optical differences at specific spectral regions, resultant from a limited number of structural or chemical differences. The correspondence between spectral mean and vegetation type is likely to be limited by spectral differences not being concentrated a one region of the spectrum. Spectral differences occurring at both low and high wavelengths, overall result in an in-between spectral mean that is similar and does not account for internal spectral complexity. 

When ordinated, spectral signatures will discriminate by year, due to the potential difference of reflectance measurements made by the different sensor types used between 2018 & 2019, as well variation in flowering phenology and community compositions between the two years.  

2: How does spectral diversity relate to species richness, evenness, and soil-background?

H2: Vegetation type will significantly affect spectral diversity (H2a). Higher spectral diversity will correspond with both increases in species richness (H2b) and species evenness (H2c), with evenness having the stronger relationship (H2d). Soil-background cover will have the strongest positive influence on spectral diversity (H2e). 

H2o: Species richness, evenness, and soil-background have no effect on spectral diversity, with no visible relationship observed. 

Predicted results 

Both increases in richness and evenness correlate with higher observed spectral diversity, across an array of different grassland/prairie habitats (Cavender‐Bares et al., 2017; Schweiger et al., 2017, 2018; Wang, Gamon, Cavender-Bares, et al., 2018a; Wang and Gamon, 2019). I predict evenness will have a larger correspondence with spectral diversity, as more even representations of species are likely to increase the detection of the variable chemical and physical structures that ultimately influence spectral diversity. If richness has larger correspondence to spectral diversity, this indicates that 1) sensor resolution is sensitive enough for the detect additional species, (potentially even when at low relative abundances) and 2) this presence of additional species sufficient to significantly increase spectral diversity. 

I predict that soil-background is the strongest predictor of spectral diversity, as soil has distinctly different reflectance than vegetation (Gholizadeh et al., 2018). Furthermore, soils reflectance is variable depending on local microclimatic conditions such as moisture and roughness. This potential for plot level variability can therefore alter spectral signatures in more complex ways, resulting in soil having the largest correspondence with spectral diversity. 


3: Does band selection influence correspondence between spectral diversity and vegetation types 

H3. Both band selection via using a subset spectral region, as well as spectral zone unmixing will result in greater correspondence between spectral diversity and vegetation type (H3a). spectral zone unmixing will result in the selection of a small but spectrally diversity subset of bands (H3a), with overall regions in the visible part of the spectrum (400-700nm) having higher correspondence with vegetation type than bands in the near infrared range (700-100nm) (H3b). 

H3o: Band selection does not visible influence the correspondence between spectral diversity and vegetation type. There are no specific spectral regions that are best suited to discriminate vegetation types. 

Predicted results 

Selecting a subset of bands will result in better discrimination of vegetation types, as reducing spectral dimensionality excludes variable and noisy regions of the spectrum. Spectral mixture analysis using spectral zone unmixing will result in finding what zones of the spectrum are best suited to differentia vegetation types. This is achieved  by isolating bands that explain maximum between community variability, while exhibiting the minimum within community variability. 
 
If spectral zone unmixing (SZU) results in the selection of a small subsets of bands, this indicates that specific structural or chemical differences explain most of the spectral variation between the two vegetation types. Due to shared life histories, the two vegetation types would have traits that are similar, aside from key divergent adaptations. These specific divergent traits would be most relevant for spectral discrimination. Furthermore, when collecting and disseminating spectral data, as well as running spectral analysis, high resolution measurement spectral bands/regions are more important for vegetation identification than coarsely capturing reflectance across the full spectrum. 

If SZU results in the selection of a large sub-set of bands, this indicates that the differences between the two vegetation types are complex, with many regions of the spectrum (aka structural and chemical traits) being relevant and important for vegetation type discrimination. Furthermore, if SZU results in the selection of bands that correspond with and/or are not visually better than an informal literature derived selection of spectral bands, this indicates that structural and chemical differences may be relatively convergent between different Arctic vegetation types. This implies that trends between biological traits and spectral diversity may be generalizable, and that future research can aim to work at greater scales of observation, rather than synthesizing the findings at small sites. Furthermore, this is promising for the development of future satellites, as potentially selection of spectral regions may be sufficient to discriminate vegetation types. 

If spectral regions in the visible spectrum (~400-700 nm) are found to best discriminate vegetation types, then chemical traits are primarily responsible for the key spectral differences between vegetation types. This spectral region corresponds with wavelengths carotenoid absorption (502-511 & 533 nm) green light reflectance (~550 nm), and chlorophyll absorption (644, 653, 672 nm). If spectral regions in the red-edge transition and near infra-red plateau (700-1000 nm) are found to best discriminate vegetation types, then physical structures are primarily responsible for the key spectral differences between vegetation types. 




4: Are closer measurements more similar than more distant measurements? 

H4: When tested for spatial autocorrelation, closer measurements will be more similar than more distant measurements (H4a), with no visible autocorrelation occurring across vegetation type areas (H4a). 

H4o: There is no visible level of autocorrelation between measurements at any distance.

Predicted results 

Spatial autocorrelation of measurements will be present but weak between proximal plots and negligible at a regional scale, due to the between plot variability of both species composition and environmental factors such as wetness and roughness. 


5: Do plot and airborne spectra differ from each other?  Does plot or airborne spectra show more variation among vegetation types?

H5: Plot and airborne spectra do visually differ from each other (H5a), with plot spectra showing more variation both within vegetation types (H5b), and between vegetation types (H5c).

H5o: There is no visible difference between plot and airborne spectra, with neither accounting more variation among vegetation types.   


Predicted results 

I predict that plot spectra show more variance within vegetation types, as they measure a smaller spatial area, resulting in only subsets of the full variation present in a vegetation type to be observed. This higher sensor resolution captures more small-scale compositional variation in each individual measurement. If plot spectra show more variance between vegetation types, then these captured small-scale compositional differences are important factors for discriminating vegetation types. It also indicates that future work that aims to use remotely-sensed spectral data for biodiversity assessment should aim to have a pixel size smaller than individual plants and structures, ensuring that each measurement is of a single or small subset of species.

Airborne spectra how lower spatial resolution, with each pixel potentially including multiple species resulting in the combined spectral signatures to be measured by the sensor. I predict that this will homogenize spectral diversity, with less variation being observed between individual measurements within a vegetation type. Furthermore, reduced spatial resolution will increase the likelihood of capturing external environmental factors, such as exposed soil or canopy structure which are likely to add noise to measurements.  This will result in less vegetation specific spectral information being captured, reducing the differentiation between types.
 If airborne spectra do show more variance between vegetation types, then course optical differences and capturing the full potential compositional variation in each measurement are more important for discriminating vegetation types. Alternatively, there might be a correlation between vegetation type and environmental factors that alters the airborne spectral signatures, resulting in greater spectral variation among the vegetation types. 


6: Can airborne remotely-sensed spectral diversity be used to identify vegetation types at the island scale?

H6: Airborne remotely-sensed spectral diversity can be used to identify vegetation types at an island scale (H6a), and when visually compared, will correspond with an existent mapping vegetation type (H6b).  

H6o: Airborne remotely-sensed spectral diversity cannot be used to identify vegetation types at an island scale, and when visually compared does not correspond with an existent mapping of vegetation types. 

Predictions 

Airborne remotely-sensed spectra diversity should be able to identify vegetation types, based on categorical spectral classifications. Through isolating the most discriminative areas of the spectrum, when mapped new spatial classified vegetation types should visually correspond with an existent vegetation classification on Qikiqtaruk (Obu et al., 2017).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
My study aims to discriminate, and map vegetation types based on their hyperspectral signatures, as well as test the relationship between spectral diversity 1) species richness 2) species evenness 3) soil background and 4) scale of observation. 
The analysis conducted will rely on plot level, as well as remotely sensed data collected Team Shrub in previous years of field work on Qikiqtaruk-Herschel Island. The hyperspectral signature of an individual or community is the unique expression of electromagnetic radiation interacting with physical plant structures (Schweiger et al., 2018). Different vegetation types have dissimilar chemical, anatomical, and morphological traits, which alter the absorbance and scattering of light, resulting in the distinct patterns reflectance that compose a spectral signature (Cavender‐Bares et al., 2017). It will be aimed to identify Herschel and Komakuk vegetation types based on the mean and variance in spectral signatures. This will use spectral data gathered from a regional field survey on the two vegetation types.  Detailed data obtained from long-term plot monitoring, will be used to build a linear model that predicts how species richness, evenness, and soil-background influence spectral diversity. What spectral regions are most relevant at discriminating vegetation types will be investigated, by sub-setting the full spectrum into regions of bands. Band selection will occur through 1) informal literature derived selection of spectral bands and 2) performing spectral band unmixing for optimal band selection. Spectral measurements will be tested for spatial autocorrelation using a variogram. Plot spectral data will be compared to airborne hyperspectral data measured at a plane scale. These airborne spectra will also be used to identify vegetation types. Categorical spectral classifications will be created and applied to remotely sensed spectral data to create a predictive map of the spatial distributions of vegetation types across Qikiqtaruk- Herschel Island.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: My study relies on pre-existing data, that was compiled by other researches in previous years of field work and open access data (“JPL | AVIRIS”, 2019; Obu et al., 2016). I have not been granted access to any of the data thus far, and therefore have not conducted any summary statistics or exploratory analysis. Analysis will commence upon completion of the preregistration process. In supplementary information given by one of my supervisors, I have been made aware that the variability within spectral signatures tend to be better at discriminating vegetation types than the difference in means.

question.value: The analysis conducted will rely on plot level, as well as remotely sensed data collected by Team Shrub in previous years of field work (2018-19) on Qikiqtaruk-Herschel Island. 6 (1x1 m) long-term monitory plots have been established - each of the two vegetation communities (Komakuk and Herschel type). No blinding or randomization took place during the data collation process, as my analysis exclusively relied on previously collected data. From this existing data, point-framing data, and percent soil-background can be obtained. During point-framing sampling, present species are also recorded, which can be used to calculate the species biodiversity metrics of species richness and evenness. Regional plot scale hyperspectral data exists for both vegetation types. Vegetation type A is partitioned into plots and has data from both 2018 & 2019, while vegetation type B only has data available for 2019, obtained from a greater region without plot subdivision. Percent soil-background data across Qikiqtaruk exists at a drone scale of observation. Plane scale hyperspectral imagery is available from a mission conducted last summer by NASA, which passed over Qikiqtaruk on two occasions (early and late July)

q13.value: For each of the two vegetation types, 6 long term monitoring plots exist, which will all be utilized in this analysis. Each plot was partitioned into 9 measurement points, with 2 replicate spectral measurements occurring at each point using a GER 1500 field spectrometer (350–1050 nm; 512 bands, spectral resolution 3 nm, spectral sampling 1.5 nm). Regional plot scale hyperspectral data exists for both vegetation types. Vegetation type A is partitioned into 30 plots and has data from both 2018 & 2019, while vegetation type B only has data available for 2019, obtained from 30 non-georeferenced plots across a greater region. 3 measurements were taken at different areas within the plot.  Remotely sensed hyperspectral data span across Qikiqtaruk-Herschel Island at two different dates (2.7.2019 & 27.7.2019) a spatial resolution of 5m per pixel.

q14.value: Sample size for this study was predetermined by the existing data and the amount of long-term sampling plots, which will all be utilized in analysis. The sample size of the landscape-wide spectral measurements was determined by data availability, which was constrained by the time available to conduct field measurements. The rational for including both 2018 and 2019 plot scale spectral data is evaluating the variance of repeat measurements as different sensor types were used between the years.

question.value:
Spectral mean: Mean value of spectral band at given wavelength (continuous variable)
Spectral reflectance (CV): The average between image variance for each spectral band (continuous variable)

Vegetation type: If the vegetation corresponds with Herschel or Komakuk type (categorical variable)
Species richness: Number of species present in plot (continuous variable)
Species evenness: Relative abundance of species in a plot (continuous variable)
Soil-background: Percent of bare soil hits obtained during point-framing (continuous variable)
See attached file:

I will use R (v 3.5.2) to conduct general linear modeling and ordinations. 

1: Can Arctic Vegetation types be identified based on the mean and variance of hyperspectral signatures? 

Multiple linear regressions will be run to test if hyperspectral signatures of different vegetation types differ significantly from each other. 

Spectral mean ~ vegetation type + plot + year

Spectral variance (CVb) ~ vegetation type + plot + year

Both spectral mean and spectral variance will be used as response variables of hyperspectral signatures. 


2: How does spectral diversity relate to species richness, evenness, canopy cover, and soil-background?

The following model will be run to quantify relative contribution species richness, evenness, and soil-background on spectral diversity. 

Spectral diversity (CV) ~ vegetation type + richness + evenness + Soil-background

Spectral diversity will be ordinated using PCA, to identify which components best explain the variation in spectral diversity. 
One ordination plot will then be produced, and points will be discriminated by each variable.
 
3: What parts of the full spectrum best discriminate vegetation types? 

The band selection methods of using a defined subset of spectral bands and spectral band unmixing will be used to reduce dimensionality of spectral data. Spectral variance will be re-calculated, based on these new subsets and spectral data, the same model as question 1 will be used to assess how band selection affects correspondence between spectral variance and vegetation type. 


Spectral variance (CVb) ~ vegetation type + plot + year

q20.value: During ordination, variables will be standardized to zero mean and unit variance.

q21.value: Variables in linear models will be considered to be significant, if the upper and lower bounds of the 95 percent credible interval do not cause the estimated effect size to cross zero. The results of all statistical tests will be reported, even if these contradict hypothesized direction or are non-significant.

q22.value: All relevant available field data will we used in data analysis, with additional meta-data such as year being used when appropriate. Extreme outliers in measurement data, that are resultant of spectrometer malfunctioning will be excluded. Field reflectance spectra will be subset from 287-1094 nm to 400–985 nm due to the radiometer sensor noise at the edges of the detection range.

q24.value:
4: Are closer measurements more similar than more distant measurements? 

This will be assessed using spatial autocorrelation analysis conducted in R and a variogram. 

5: Do plot and airborne spectra differ?  Do plot or airborne spectra show more variation among vegetation types?

This will be assessed by visual comparison of the spectrally normalized differences between plot and airborne spectra, using the previously described equation for spectral normalization (equation 5) 


6: Can airborne remotely-sensed spectral diversity be used to identify vegetation types at the island scale?
Categorical spectral classifications will be created and applied to remotely-sensed spectral data to create a predictive map of the spatial distributions of vegetation types across Qikiqtaruk- Herschel Island. This created map will be visually compaired to an existent mapping of vegetation types across Qikiqtaruk ((Obu et al., 2016).

6: Can airborne remotely-sensed spectral diversity be used to identify vegetation types at the island scale?

H6: Airborne remotely-sensed spectral diversity can be used to identify vegetation types at an island scale (H6a), and when visually compared, will correspond with an existent mapping vegetation type (H6b).  

H6o: Airborne remotely-sensed spectral diversity cannot be used to identify vegetation types at an island scale, and when visually compared does not correspond with an existent mapping of vegetation types. 

Predictions 

Airborne remotely-sensed spectra diversity should be able to identify vegetation types, based on categorical spectral classifications. Through isolating the most discriminative areas of the spectrum, when mapped new spatial classified vegetation types should visually correspond with an existent vegetation classification on Qikiqtaruk (Obu et al., 2017).

registration_responses.q11: My study relies on pre-existing data, that was compiled by other researches in previous years of field work and open access data (“JPL | AVIRIS”, 2019; Obu et al., 2016). I have not been granted access to any of the data thus far, and therefore have not conducted any summary statistics or exploratory analysis. Analysis will commence upon completion of the preregistration process. In supplementary information given by one of my supervisors, I have been made aware that the variability within spectral signatures tend to be better at discriminating vegetation types than the difference in means.
registration_responses.q13: For each of the two vegetation types, 6 long term monitoring plots exist, which will all be utilized in this analysis. Each plot was partitioned into 9 measurement points, with 2 replicate spectral measurements occurring at each point using a GER 1500 field spectrometer (350–1050 nm; 512 bands, spectral resolution 3 nm, spectral sampling 1.5 nm). Regional plot scale hyperspectral data exists for both vegetation types. Vegetation type A is partitioned into 30 plots and has data from both 2018 & 2019, while vegetation type B only has data available for 2019, obtained from 30 non-georeferenced plots across a greater region. 3 measurements were taken at different areas within the plot.  Remotely sensed hyperspectral data span across Qikiqtaruk-Herschel Island at two different dates (2.7.2019 & 27.7.2019) a spatial resolution of 5m per pixel.
registration_responses.q14: Sample size for this study was predetermined by the existing data and the amount of long-term sampling plots, which will all be utilized in analysis. The sample size of the landscape-wide spectral measurements was determined by data availability, which was constrained by the time available to conduct field measurements. The rational for including both 2018 and 2019 plot scale spectral data is evaluating the variance of repeat measurements as different sensor types were used between the years.
registration_responses.q20: During ordination, variables will be standardized to zero mean and unit variance.
registration_responses.q21: Variables in linear models will be considered to be significant, if the upper and lower bounds of the 95 percent credible interval do not cause the estimated effect size to cross zero. The results of all statistical tests will be reported, even if these contradict hypothesized direction or are non-significant.
registration_responses.q22: All relevant available field data will we used in data analysis, with additional meta-data such as year being used when appropriate. Extreme outliers in measurement data, that are resultant of spectrometer malfunctioning will be excluded. Field reflectance spectra will be subset from 287-1094 nm to 400–985 nm due to the radiometer sensor noise at the edges of the detection range.
registration_responses.q24:
4: Are closer measurements more similar than more distant measurements? 

This will be assessed using spatial autocorrelation analysis conducted in R and a variogram. 

5: Do plot and airborne spectra differ?  Do plot or airborne spectra show more variation among vegetation types?

This will be assessed by visual comparison of the spectrally normalized differences between plot and airborne spectra, using the previously described equation for spectral normalization (equation 5) 


6: Can airborne remotely-sensed spectral diversity be used to identify vegetation types at the island scale?
Categorical spectral classifications will be created and applied to remotely-sensed spectral data to create a predictive map of the spatial distributions of vegetation types across Qikiqtaruk- Herschel Island. This created map will be visually compaired to an existent mapping of vegetation types across Qikiqtaruk ((Obu et al., 2016).

registration_responses.q8.question:
My study aims to discriminate, and map vegetation types based on their hyperspectral signatures, as well as test the relationship between spectral diversity 1) species richness 2) species evenness 3) soil background and 4) scale of observation. 
The analysis conducted will rely on plot level, as well as remotely sensed data collected Team Shrub in previous years of field work on Qikiqtaruk-Herschel Island. The hyperspectral signature of an individual or community is the unique expression of electromagnetic radiation interacting with physical plant structures (Schweiger et al., 2018). Different vegetation types have dissimilar chemical, anatomical, and morphological traits, which alter the absorbance and scattering of light, resulting in the distinct patterns reflectance that compose a spectral signature (Cavender‐Bares et al., 2017). It will be aimed to identify Herschel and Komakuk vegetation types based on the mean and variance in spectral signatures. This will use spectral data gathered from a regional field survey on the two vegetation types.  Detailed data obtained from long-term plot monitoring, will be used to build a linear model that predicts how species richness, evenness, and soil-background influence spectral diversity. What spectral regions are most relevant at discriminating vegetation types will be investigated, by sub-setting the full spectrum into regions of bands. Band selection will occur through 1) informal literature derived selection of spectral bands and 2) performing spectral band unmixing for optimal band selection. Spectral measurements will be tested for spatial autocorrelation using a variogram. Plot spectral data will be compared to airborne hyperspectral data measured at a plane scale. These airborne spectra will also be used to identify vegetation types. Categorical spectral classifications will be created and applied to remotely sensed spectral data to create a predictive map of the spatial distributions of vegetation types across Qikiqtaruk- Herschel Island.
registration_responses.q12.question: The analysis conducted will rely on plot level, as well as remotely sensed data collected by Team Shrub in previous years of field work (2018-19) on Qikiqtaruk-Herschel Island. 6 (1x1 m) long-term monitory plots have been established - each of the two vegetation communities (Komakuk and Herschel type). No blinding or randomization took place during the data collation process, as my analysis exclusively relied on previously collected data. From this existing data, point-framing data, and percent soil-background can be obtained. During point-framing sampling, present species are also recorded, which can be used to calculate the species biodiversity metrics of species richness and evenness. Regional plot scale hyperspectral data exists for both vegetation types. Vegetation type A is partitioned into plots and has data from both 2018 & 2019, while vegetation type B only has data available for 2019, obtained from a greater region without plot subdivision. Percent soil-background data across Qikiqtaruk exists at a drone scale of observation. Plane scale hyperspectral imagery is available from a mission conducted last summer by NASA, which passed over Qikiqtaruk on two occasions (early and late July)
registration_responses.q16.question:
Spectral mean: Mean value of spectral band at given wavelength (continuous variable)
Spectral reflectance (CV): The average between image variance for each spectral band (continuous variable)
registration_responses.q17.question:
Vegetation type: If the vegetation corresponds with Herschel or Komakuk type (categorical variable)
Species richness: Number of species present in plot (continuous variable)
Species evenness: Relative abundance of species in a plot (continuous variable)
Soil-background: Percent of bare soil hits obtained during point-framing (continuous variable)
registration_responses.q18.question: See attached file:
registration_responses.q19.question:
I will use R (v 3.5.2) to conduct general linear modeling and ordinations. 

1: Can Arctic Vegetation types be identified based on the mean and variance of hyperspectral signatures? 

Multiple linear regressions will be run to test if hyperspectral signatures of different vegetation types differ significantly from each other. 

Spectral mean ~ vegetation type + plot + year

Spectral variance (CVb) ~ vegetation type + plot + year

Both spectral mean and spectral variance will be used as response variables of hyperspectral signatures. 


2: How does spectral diversity relate to species richness, evenness, canopy cover, and soil-background?

The following model will be run to quantify relative contribution species richness, evenness, and soil-background on spectral diversity. 

Spectral diversity (CV) ~ vegetation type + richness + evenness + Soil-background

Spectral diversity will be ordinated using PCA, to identify which components best explain the variation in spectral diversity. 
One ordination plot will then be produced, and points will be discriminated by each variable.
 
3: What parts of the full spectrum best discriminate vegetation types? 

The band selection methods of using a defined subset of spectral bands and spectral band unmixing will be used to reduce dimensionality of spectral data. Spectral variance will be re-calculated, based on these new subsets and spectral data, the same model as question 1 will be used to assess how band selection affects correspondence between spectral variance and vegetation type. 


Spectral variance (CVb) ~ vegetation type + plot + year

attributes.title: Scope Sensitivity, Sources Cues, and Equivalency Framing in Support for Policy

q1.value: Scope Sensitivity, Sources Cues, and Equivalency Framing in Support for Policy

q2.value: Alexander Sahn | Amy Lerman | Laura Stoker

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

registration_responses.q1: Scope Sensitivity, Sources Cues, and Equivalency Framing in Support for Policy
registration_responses.q2: Alexander Sahn | Amy Lerman | Laura Stoker
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

q2.value: The project will test competing hypotheses of how the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has affected sleep patterns. By one view, COVID-19 has increased stress and cognitive arousal, which should lead to poorer sleep quantity and quality. By the alternative view, COVID-19 has reduced early morning schedule requirements, lessened time-sensitive work demands, and simplified people's to-do lists to the essentials, thereby improving sleep quantity and quality. A combination of these views may also be possible: with fewer scheduling demands people may sleep longer during the COVID-19 quarantine period yet have worse overall sleep quality due to elevated stress and cognitive arousal.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Repeated measures and cross-sectional mixed design. A subset of U.S. participants completed a sleep survey via Mechanical Turk in February 2020 prior to COVID-19 social distancing and quarantine policies. We will attempt to recruit these participants to repeat the survey in mid-late March 2020 during the ongoing social distancing/quarantine period. To increase the sample size, we will additionally recruit another group of U.S. participants who did not have pre-quarantine baseline measures.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value: The only existing data are the baseline, pre-quarantine data (from February 2020). The data were initially collected for a different reason--to examine the association between sleep and music habits--but we realized in March 2020 that they could serve as useful baseline data to examine changes in sleep habits as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and quarantine policies. We are registering this study prior to collecting any data during the COVID-19 quarantine period.

question.value: We will collect data via Amazon Mechanical Turk, offering $1 monetary compensation to participants. Inclusion criteria include age of 18 or older and living in the United States.

q11.value: We collected N=209 at baseline (February 2020). We will invite all those participants to repeat the survey, but we expect attrition. We will therefore also open the survey to participants who did not complete the baseline assessment to conduct cross-sectional analyses. We will seek to recruit 500 new participants for the cross-sectional analyses.

q12.value: The primary constraint is the time period as we do not know how policies will shift even in one week's time. The sample size will give us .90 power to detect small-medium sized (d=.30) cross-sectional effects for two-tailed tests with alpha set to 0.05. We will additionally have .90 power to detect small-medium sized (r=.15) correlations between COVID-19-related worries/stressors and sleep patterns.

q13.value: Data collection will not last more than one week, or will cease if there is a major policy change that could introduce unwanted variability in the data set.

question.value: N/A

Variables in this study include demographic factors (i.e., age, gender, race, geographical location, employment status), global sleep quality, vulnerability to stress-related sleep disturbance, self-reported changes in sleep patterns before and after the COVID-19 quarantine, chronotype, sleepiness, and intraindividual variability in sleep, COVID-19-related experiences, overall health, and caffeine intake.

We will measure sleep patterns before and after COVID-19 quarantine by asking participants to report their habitual bedtime, sleep latency, get-up time, sleep duration, and the number of awakenings throughout the night before and after the quarantine/social distancing period. We will additionally ask participants to report whether they experienced changes in how well-rested they feel after the quarantine/social distancing policies on a 7 point scale.

Subjective sleep quality is measured by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) at baseline and follow-up. PSQI is a 9-item questionnaire assessing subjective sleep quality in seven domains: subjective sleep quality, sleep latency, sleep duration, habitual sleep efficiency, sleep disturbances, use of sleep medication, and daytime dysfunction. These component scores yield a global sleep quality index that is widely used. To better capture the COVID-19 quarantine time interval, at the follow up assessment we will modify the PSQI to refer to sleep over the past two weeks whereas at baseline we used the typical reference time period of the past month. 

Vulnerability to stress-related sleep disturbance is measured by the Ford Insomnia Response to Stress Test (FIRST). FIRST asks participants to rate the likelihood of experiencing difficulty sleeping in 9 stressful situations on a 4-point scale from "Not likely" to "Very likely". 

Chronotype is measured by the last item on the Morningness-Eveningness Questionnaire: "One hears about “morning” and “evening” types of people. Which one of these types do you consider yourself to be?" Participants will select one of the four options: "Definitely a 'morning' type," "Rather more a 'morning' than an 'evening' type," "Rather more an 'evening' than a 'morning' type," and "Definitely an 'evening' type".

Sleepiness is measured by the Stanford Sleepiness Scale. Participants will rate how sleepy they feel at the moment using a 7-point likert scale (from "Feeling active, vital, alert, or wide awake" to "No longer fighting sleep, sleep onset soon; having dream-like thoughts").

Intraindividual variability in sleep is measured by a new questionnaire we developed. We will ask participants to report their typical sleep on each day of the week (i.e., bedtime, get-up time, sleep duration, sleep latency, and napping). Additionally, we will ask participants to rate the extent to which their sleep fluctuates across weekday nights and from weekday nights to weekend nights. 

Furthermore, we will ask participants to report COVID-19-related experiences, including whether their local government has issued shelter-in-place (or stay-at-home) orders, whether they or people around them have showed symptoms of COVID-19 or have been tested positive for COVID-19, and whether their responsibilities changed during COVID-19 quarantine. In addition, participants will rate the extent to which they agree or disagree with ten statements related to COVID-19. For example, "I learned a lot of scientific knowledge about COVID-19."

Participants will also rate their overall health using a 4 point scale (from "Poor" to "Excellent") and report their caffeine intake.

For the subset of participants who completed the surveys in mid-February and late-March, We will calculate the changes in their sleep patterns. For example, if a participant reported sleeping for 7 hours in February and 8 hours in March, we will subtract 7 from 8 to quantify changes in sleep.

We will use t tests to assess whether sleep patterns changed during the COVID-19 quarantine. For the subset of participants who reported their sleep in mid-February and late-March, we will use paired-sample t tests to assess changes in sleep. For the participants who only reported their sleep in mid-March, we will use independent-samples t tests to compare their sleep with the baseline sample.

q19.value: All statistical tests will be two-tailed. Results with p-values < .05 will be considered statistically significant.

q20.value: We will exclude data points that have impossible values (e.g., sleeping for 25 hours/day).

q21.value: Missing data will not be included in the analyses.

q22.value: We will examine correlations between COVID-19 stressors/experiences and sleep quantity/quality. We will examine whether demographic factors influence sleep quantity/quality.

attributes.title: Genetic Predispositions and Caregiving Behaviour interact in modulating Virtual Social Attitudes in Humans
attributes.description: The interaction between parental care and the oxytocin receptor (OXTR) gene affect social behaviours in adulthood. Serotonin transporter gene polymorphisms (5-HTTLPR) and early parent-infant interaction influence adults’ relationship with intimate partners. However, human conspecifics socially act towards the real and virtual world in displaying multiple and complex social interactions. Hence, the mechanisms underlying the virtual social relationship in humans remain largely unknown. We hypothesized interaction between genetic factors (three polymorphisms from the oxytocin receptor, OXTR, and the serotonin transporter, 5-HTTLPR), parental bonding patterns (PBI) and adults’ interactional patterns (ASQ, ECR-R) in shaping virtual social behaviour (Instagram, Facebook). Self-reported questionnaires were used to evaluate participants’ (n= 61) parental bonding patterns (Parental Bonding Instrument, formed by four subscales Maternal Care, Paternal Care, Maternal Overprotection, Paternal Overprotection), interactional patterns towards peers (Attachment Style Questionnaire formed by five subscales Confidence, Discomfort in Intimacy, Relationship as Secondary, Need for Approval, Worry about Relationship) and the quality of bond with intimate partners (Experience in Close Relationship Scale formed by two subscales Anxiety, Avoidance). Social media activities were collected applying an automatic Python algorithm through which eight indexes were extracted: Instagram number of following users, followers, posts and tags from other users’ posts and Facebook number of friends, interests, published pics and given likes. Buccal mucosa cell samples were collected to assess participants’ genetic predispositions, and regions OXTR/rs2254298 (G/G homozygotes vs A carriers), OXTR/rs53576 (G/G homozygotes vs A carriers) and 5-HTTLPR/rs255331 (G/G homozygotes vs A carriers) were genotyped. We hypothesize multiple gene*environment interactions on different parameters and indexes calculated on the social media variables as Instagram Followers/Following ratio (“Social Desirability Index”).

q1.value: Andrea Bonassi, Ilaria Cataldo, Giulio Gabrieli, Bruno Lepri, Gianluca Esposito

q2.value:
In previous investigations (Bonassi and colleagues, 2019 and 2020), we developed a model from behavioural genetics to explain Instagram behaviour. As regarded Oxytocin Receptor Gene (OXTR), the polymorphism rs2245298 and the quality in the early parental bonding moderated users' sociability in terms of posts' number and Social Desirability Index (SDI). Although we uncovered a potential influence of the individual development on Instagram social behaviour, the impact of quality in the relationship with adult peers has not yet been explored under a gene-environment perspective. This project deals with this lack by probing how the interaction between genetic factors (OXTR/rs2254298, OXTR/rs53576) and adult bonding with peers (Confidence, Discomfort with Closeness, Relationships as Secondary, Need for Approval, Preoccupation with Relationships) shapes virtual social behaviour on Instagram (number of published posts, followers, followings and the SDI, an index calculated by the ratio between the number of followers and the number of followings). Given that human behaviours are the result of combined interactions between genes and individual experiences, the question is if online social behaviour (Instagram) of vulnerable genetic carriers can be modulated by the offline relationship with friends or peers.
For each Instagram dependent variable, we hypothesize an interaction between genetic factors and peer attachment scores. Independently from gender, we predict that 1) adult Instagram users with genetic risk factor (OXTR rs224529 A carriers, OXTR rs53576 G carriers) and a positive and friendly relationship with peers (High Confidence, Low Discomfort with Closeness, Low Relationships as Secondary, Low Need for Approval, Low Preoccupation with Relationships) will show a higher number of posts and SDI compared to less vulnerable genetic carriers (OXTR rs224529 G/G homozygotes, OXTR rs53576 A/A homozygotes). Oppositely, 2) adult users with genetic risk factor and a negative and conflicting relationship with peers (Low Confidence, High Discomfort with Closeness, High Relationships as Secondary, High Need for Approval, High Preoccupation with Relationships) will show a lower number of posts and a lower SDI compared to less vulnerable genetic carriers.
We provide three analytical and theoretical justifications which lead us to test our hypothesis limited to Instagram number of posts and SDI. Firstly, the selection of two main dependent variables allows maintaining a conservative approach to data, avoiding extreme corrections due to multiple tests comparison. Secondly, the number of posts specifies the quantity of published content among the following people. We consider it an objective measure of the personal inclination to broadcast information among users. Moreover, the SDI provides a value of the balance between the number of followers and followings for each user's account. In previous research (Bonassi et al., 2019), we estimated this index to test a reliable parameter of general sociability, explained in terms of lower or higher asymmetry of the individual social network.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a mixed design study with Instagram social behaviour (number of posts, SDI) values as the dependent variable, the OXTR gene genotype (OXTR rs224529 G/G homozygotes vs A carriers,  OXTR rs53576 A/A homozygotes vs G carriers) as a between-subject factor, and the ASQ dimensions (Confidence, Discomfort with Closeness, Relationships as Secondary, Need for Approval, Preoccupation with Relationships) as continuous covariates.

q7.value: This study will not require randomization.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: Existing data were processed and structured in a database by two experimenters. The access to the final dataframe will be allowed to a unique researcher once the pre-registration is finalized.

question.value: Before beginning the experiment, each participant signed the informed consent (no-risk warranty, health history and data policy) for each assessment, supplying information about gender, age and ethnicity. First, participants completed an online self-report questionnaire (Attachment Style Questionnaire) to evaluate their attachment status with peers (behavioural assessment). Secondly, buccal mucosa was assessed from each participant by using sterile cotton swabs for DNA analysis (genetic assessment). Finally, participants provided their own online Instagram link and an ad-hoc Python script extracted three parameters representative of the virtual social behaviours (social media assessment). When the automatic script failed, Instagram data were collected manually.

q11.value: Non-parent Singaporean adults (n = 61) aged 18-26 were recruited among the students of the Nanyang Technological University (Singapore). Exclusion criteria were: (I) current or lifetime history of genetic, neurological or psychiatric disorder, (II) age higher than 30 years, (III) not being Instagram users. Four participants were not included due to failure in a) questionnaires' online compilation or b) Instagram data extraction. In the end, our sample consisted of 58 Singaporean adults (16 males). The Ethical Committee of Nanyang Technological University approved the research (IRB-2015-08-020-01), which was conducted in line with the Declaration of Helsinki. Bio-samples containing buccal mucosa were anonymized and sent to the laboratory for genotyping. Instagram data and questionnaire data were anonymized at the beginning of the data collection.

q12.value: Considering that study constraints influence the sample size during the data collection, we calculated the effect size by implementing sensitivity power analysis in GPower software for Instagram number of posts and SDI, respectively. In the sensitivity analysis, we considered analysis of covariance (ANCOVA: fixed effects, main effects and interactions). Input parameters corrected the alpha at 0.025 and set Power at 0.90, total sample size at 58, numerator degrees of freedom at 1, number of groups at 2, number of covariates at 5. After the calculation, the output parameters showed a large effect size (0.47). This parameter is in line with previous studies which found a statistical power equal between 0.90 and 0.99 given a large effect size (for example, see Truzzi et al., 2018; Bonassi et al., 2020). Moreover, interaction effects between peer attachment and genotype will also be analyzed by two Student's t-test. Given that the researcher has not yet permitted to access the dataset, it is not possible to estimate the sample size of the two comparing groups required for a sensitivity analysis (corrected alpha at 0.025, expected Power at 0.80). Therefore, for each significant gene*environment interaction, the power of two one-tailed Student's t-tests (difference between two independent means) will be calculated post-hoc.

q13.value: As many participants as possible were sampled in three months.

question.value: This is an observational study. Therefore, manipulated variables are not included.

We collected genetic, environmental and Instagram (IG) data as hypothesis-driven measured variables.
A specific description of the measured genetic and environmental variables follows:
1) Environmental measure: attachment from the Adult Style Questionnaire. The Adult Style Questionnaire (ASQ) is a 40-item self-report questionnaire adopted to measure the individual self-perception of the quality in the adult interpersonal relationships. Five ASQ Dimensions are evaluated and considered: 
a) ASQ Confidence is an integer variable which reports the ASQ scores for the Confidence Dimension.
b) ASQ Discomfort with Closeness is an integer variable which reports the ASQ scores for the Discomfort with Closeness Dimension.
c) ASQ Relationships as Secondary is an integer variable which reports the ASQ scores for the Relationships as Secondary Dimension.
d) ASQ Need for Approval is an integer variable which reports the ASQ scores for the Need for Approval Dimension.
e) ASQ Preoccupation with Relationships is an integer variable which reports the ASQ scores for the Preoccupation with Relationships Dimension.
2) Genetic measure: Oxytocin Receptor Gene. The regions rs2245298 and rs53576 of the Oxytocin Receptor Gene (OXTR) are a-priori considered because of their robust association with social behaviour, empathy, affect and adult attachment.
a) OXTR rs53576 is a categorical variable (levels: A/A, A/G, G/G) which contains the genotypes for the OXTR region rs53576.
b) OXTR rs2254298 is a categorical variable (levels: A/A, G/A, G/G) which includes the genotypes for the OXTR region rs2254298.
3) An ad-hoc prepared Python script extracted three a-priori elected parameters representative of the Instagram (IG) social behaviours. 
The following two parameters represent the main measured dependent variables included in the confirmatory analyses of this study:
a) IG posts is an integer variable which contains the Instagram number of published posts.
b) IG SDI is an integer variable which includes the estimate produced by the ratio between the number of followers and followings.
The following measured dependent variables are reported for exploratory analyses and unexpected effects of this study:
a) IG followings is an integer variable which includes the Instagram number of followed users.
b) IG followers is an integer variable which includes the Instagram number of followers.

Every variable extracted from Instagram represents a snapshot of participants' social behaviour at a specific time point. As described above, one index will be calculated for the confirmatory analyses: the SDI.

We hypothesize two genotype*environment interactions (OXTR rs2254298 SNP * reported adult attachment and OXTR rs53576 SNP * reported adult attachment) on IG number of posts and SDI. 
The genetic variables, respectively OXTR rs2245298 and OXTR rs53576, will be used in separated analysis as predictors of the measured variables IG posts and IG SDI, while the ASQ subscales will be considered as covariates. Statistical analysis will be conducted by R software. 
Data approach and statistical techniques will follow these steps: 
a) Dataset will be imported in R and NA values will be quantified for each variable.
b) Data related to subjects with NA values higher than 2 will be discarded.
c) Genotypes' frequencies for the regions OXTR rs53576 (A/A vs A/G vs G/G) and rs2254298 (A/A, G/A, G/G) will be calculated.
d) Participants possessing at least one allele (i.e. G/G homozygotes or G/A) will be classified into a single carriers group, and the obtained genotype distribution (i.e. A/A homozygotes vs G carriers) will be compared with the Hardy–Weinberg Equilibrium.
e) The SDI will be obtained, dividing the IG followers by the IG followings.  
f) IG variables will be standardized in z-scores.
g) Male and female participants will be checked for significant differences between the allelic groups and within each IG variable. 
h) In our sample, Cronbach's alphas will be calculated for each subscale of the ASQ questionnaire. 
i) Prior to data analysis, the data distribution of each dependent variable will be displayed by density plots and box-plots; skew and kurtosis will be calculated to understand the related power values. 
j) To each dependent variable whose sampling will not show a Gaussian distribution, a logarithmic transformation will be applied. Therefore, a statistical parametric test will be adopted.
k) Bartlett test will verify the preliminary assumption of equal variance across the sample for the analysis of covariance (ANCOVA).
l) For each IG variable, one ANCOVA will be performed with the IG posts number as the dependent variable, the OXTR gene genotype (OXTR rs53576 A/A homozygotes vs G carriers) as a between-subjects factor and the ASQ dimensions all together (Confidence, Discomfort with Closeness, Relationships as Secondary, Need for Approval, Preoccupation with Relationships) as continuous covariates. For each IG variable one ANCOVA will also be performed with the OXTr gene genotype rs224529 (G/G homozygotes vs A carriers) as a between-subjects factor, and the other parameters unchanged.
m) If a gender effect is preliminarily found on an IG dependent variable, the variable "Gender" will be included as a between-subjects factor in the ANCOVA on the same IG variable. 
n) Correlations will be run as post hoc tests, and Pearsons’ r coefficients will be used to strength of the effect of the covariate on the dependent variable and Cohen’s d will be used to evaluate the magnitude of effects which will be found to be significant.
o) Scores in the ASQ dimensions are distributed on a continuum, which will enable us to identify the ASQ subscales 1) as covariates applied to the ANCOVA, 2) as ten main groups by clustering the sample using the median splits for the post-hoc tests: low Confidence, low Discomfort with Closeness, low Relationships as Secondary, low Need for Approval, low Preoccupation with Relationships, high Confidence, high Discomfort with Closeness, high Relationships as Secondary, high Need for Approval, high Preoccupation with Relationships.
p) Main and interactive ANCOVA effects between variables will be considered, visualized by scatterplot with linear models.
q) Effects of the interaction between adult attachment and genotype on each IG variable will be represented by barplots and further analyzed by post-hoc t-tests.

q18.value: The dependent variables which will not show a Gaussian data distribution will be log-transformed in order to perform statistical parametric tests. The cubic root data transformation method will be applied if the logarithmic transformation does not properly convert the data distribution into Gaussian with skew contained between -1.5 and 1.5.

q19.value: The probability value for the given parametric statistical models (ANCOVAs) will be used to ascertain the statistical significance of the results. One-tailed post-hoc Student's t-tests will be favoured if the direction of the effect is clear and in line with the previous hypotheses. Otherwise, two-tailed post-hoc t-tests will be adopted. Alpha will be corrected proportionally to the number of repeated t-tests by Bonferroni method. Furthermore, Cohen’s d will be computed to evaluate the magnitude of significant effects in the ANCOVAs and regression coefficients will be used to assess the effects of the covariates on the dependent variable.

q20.value: For each dependent variable, data-points which differ in more than two standard deviations from the mean will be identified as outliers and replaced with the mean value in observations excluding outliers.

q21.value: For each variable of each subject, incomplete or missing data will be removed.

q22.value: Additional analyses will be conducted on the dependent variables IG followings and IG followers. Data-driven exploration will observe the same procedure adopted for the hypothesis-driven analysis and may produce unexpected and potential main and interactive effects.

registration_responses.q1: Andrea Bonassi, Ilaria Cataldo, Giulio Gabrieli, Bruno Lepri, Gianluca Esposito
registration_responses.q2:
In previous investigations (Bonassi and colleagues, 2019 and 2020), we developed a model from behavioural genetics to explain Instagram behaviour. As regarded Oxytocin Receptor Gene (OXTR), the polymorphism rs2245298 and the quality in the early parental bonding moderated users' sociability in terms of posts' number and Social Desirability Index (SDI). Although we uncovered a potential influence of the individual development on Instagram social behaviour, the impact of quality in the relationship with adult peers has not yet been explored under a gene-environment perspective. This project deals with this lack by probing how the interaction between genetic factors (OXTR/rs2254298, OXTR/rs53576) and adult bonding with peers (Confidence, Discomfort with Closeness, Relationships as Secondary, Need for Approval, Preoccupation with Relationships) shapes virtual social behaviour on Instagram (number of published posts, followers, followings and the SDI, an index calculated by the ratio between the number of followers and the number of followings). Given that human behaviours are the result of combined interactions between genes and individual experiences, the question is if online social behaviour (Instagram) of vulnerable genetic carriers can be modulated by the offline relationship with friends or peers.
For each Instagram dependent variable, we hypothesize an interaction between genetic factors and peer attachment scores. Independently from gender, we predict that 1) adult Instagram users with genetic risk factor (OXTR rs224529 A carriers, OXTR rs53576 G carriers) and a positive and friendly relationship with peers (High Confidence, Low Discomfort with Closeness, Low Relationships as Secondary, Low Need for Approval, Low Preoccupation with Relationships) will show a higher number of posts and SDI compared to less vulnerable genetic carriers (OXTR rs224529 G/G homozygotes, OXTR rs53576 A/A homozygotes). Oppositely, 2) adult users with genetic risk factor and a negative and conflicting relationship with peers (Low Confidence, High Discomfort with Closeness, High Relationships as Secondary, High Need for Approval, High Preoccupation with Relationships) will show a lower number of posts and a lower SDI compared to less vulnerable genetic carriers.
We provide three analytical and theoretical justifications which lead us to test our hypothesis limited to Instagram number of posts and SDI. Firstly, the selection of two main dependent variables allows maintaining a conservative approach to data, avoiding extreme corrections due to multiple tests comparison. Secondly, the number of posts specifies the quantity of published content among the following people. We consider it an objective measure of the personal inclination to broadcast information among users. Moreover, the SDI provides a value of the balance between the number of followers and followings for each user's account. In previous research (Bonassi et al., 2019), we estimated this index to test a reliable parameter of general sociability, explained in terms of lower or higher asymmetry of the individual social network.

attributes.title: Active word learning in infants: Sampling novel object-label associations

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Active word learning in infants: Sampling novel object-label associations

other.value:
Justification for pre-registration:
At present, the data from 67 infants has been collected (oversampling our planned sample size in anticipation of 20-30% of infants' being excluded according to our inclusion criteria). However, no data has been accessed except (a) a visual inspection of the data of the first 2 participants, to ensure that all data was being stored as expected, and (b) to move data from the lab's local computer to cloud storage, in preparation for analysis. In particular, the data has not been opened or visually inspected by any researcher involved in the analysis of the data. Thus, at the time of this pre-registration, all researchers are "blind" to the collected data. The intention in submitting the current registration is to create and register an analysis plan prior to beginning to process and analyze the data.

Along with basic demographic variables, we will also collect data on infants' productive vocabulary (short form MCDI) and analyze whether vocabulary size correlates with infants' sampling behavior. 

In addition, we will also collect test data to measure infants' learning.
Specifically, we will conduct a 2-alternative forced-choice picture-pointing task testing infants' knowledge of the 8 labels at the conclusion of the experiment.
We have no strong predictions with respect to the test data, but we will conduct exploratory analyses to investigate whether:
1. Infants successfully learn the words.
2. Infants learn more or less frequently labeled objects better.
3. Infants' learning of a particular object-label association is predicted by the frequency with which they sampled that object-label association.

sample.value: Our target sample size is 50 19- to 21-month-old infants. We conducted a power analysis for our logistic mixed-effects analysis using simulations built with the simr package in R (Green & MacLeod, 2016). We conducted simulations for a range of possible values for our main beta coefficient of interest using random effects and residual variance estimated from a pilot sample of 10 participants, for both of the two main analyses described above (in question 5/Analyses, section (a)). We found that a sample size of 50 participants would provide roughly 80% power to detect an effect of informativeness half of the size (beta=0.4) of that observed in two previous experiments (in which beta ~0.8).

analyses.value:
Main analyses:
The main analyses will test whether infants' likelihood of selecting novel-object label associations depends on the relative frequency with which two novel object-label associations were experienced during a given training block.

(a) In order to test whether the relative informativeness of object-label associations predicts infants’ sampling choices, our general analytic approach will be to test whether infants’ likelihood of choosing the more informative object-label association increases as the difference in relative frequency increases across the four training conditions. We will fit a logistic mixed-effects model predicting the likelihood of infants’ choosing a given object from the difference in frequency with which that object was labeled compared to the alternative object during the training phase (i.e. from the condition manipulation treated as a continuous predictor). We will include by-participant and by-item random intercepts and a by-participant random slope for condition. The random effects structure will be iteratively pruned until convergence is achieved, removing random effects in order of inferential importance (first removing the random effect for items, then the random slope for condition). We will also fit an analogous model in which we predict infants’ choices from the difference in informativeness of the two object-label association options. Informativeness of each object-label association will be computed as:
informativeness = - log2(relative frequency of object-label), where
relative frequency of object-label = (trials labeling the object)/(total number of training trials)
Note that since log2(0) is not defined, we will set the relative frequency of the object-label association with a frequency of 0 to be half of the lowest possible relative frequency assuming a single labeling event (i.e., 1/16).

(b) In addition to assessing the overall effect of condition, we will also test whether infants show a preference for selecting the more informative object-label association for each block/ condition, using the same logistic mixed-effects modeling approach.

Secondary analyses:
(c) The main analyses will include all sampling trials. To assess the robustness of the results, we will also fit the same models including only the first sampling trial of each block for each participant. In a previous experiment, we observed the strongest effects for the initial sampling trial.
(d) We will conduct secondary analyses using analogously constructed models to test the impact of the frequency manipulation on how long infants fixate the "selected" object during the labeling event in the Sampling Phase. Infants' fixation times will be computed using eye-tracking data collected concurrently with the experiment.

outliers.value:
Data exclusions:
Infants will be excluded for:
- experimenter error (e.g., if parents were not properly blinded to the experiment with darkened sunglasses or other procedural errors)
- poor or missing calibration (i.e., if fewer than at minimum 3 of the five calibration points are not satisfactorily calibrated for both eyes)
- general infant fussiness during the Training and/ or Sampling Phase.
- Infants must contribute at least one useable gaze-contingent sampling trial in at least two of the four blocks to be included in the analysis.

Trials will be excluded if:
- Sampling trials are not gaze-contingent (i.e., the infant does not trigger the sampling event)
- Poor eye-tracking that impacts the gaze-contingent procedure on a given sampling trial (leading to imprecise timing between infants' fixation and the sampling event)
- infant fussiness during a sampling trial.
- parental interference (e.g., pointing) during a sampling trial.

To assess the robustness of the results to different exclusion criteria, we will also conduct all analyses with a stricter exclusion criterion for sampling trials. In these analyses we will additionally exclude all gaze-contingent sampling trials in which infants required more than 2000 ms to trigger the labeling event, i.e. if infants' fixation triggering the sampling trial is not closely timed with the onset of the sampling opportunity.

dependent.value: On each sampling trial, infants have the opportunity to trigger one of two objects' label (by fixating a given object). The main dependent measure is which of two object-label associations infants trigger during the Sampling Phase (binary outcome measure). Specifically, infants' sampling choices will be coded in terms of whether they select the object-label association that they experienced less frequently (coded as 1) or more frequently (coded as 0) during training.

conditions.value: The key manipulation is a within-subjects manipulation of the relative frequency of pairs of object-label associations. The relative frequency of pairs of object-label associations will be varied across four blocks, such that children experience object-label association frequencies of 4:0 (i.e. one object is labeled four times, while the other is never given a label), 4:1, 4:2, and 4:4 in one block each. Thus, while all objects are seen equally often within a given block, the relative frequency with which the two objects are labeled varies across the four blocks of the experiment. The frequency role of the object pairs will be counterbalanced across infants. Each participant views each block/ condition once, in random order.

hypothesis.value:
The overarching goal of the project is to understand how infants seek out new information about words. In particular, do infants sample novel words that are more informative?

In the present study, we ask whether infants' likelihood of selecting novel object-label associations depends on the relative frequency of their experience with these object-label associations.
