At present, the data from 67 infants has been collected (oversampling our planned sample size in anticipation of 20-30% of infants' being excluded according to our inclusion criteria). However, no data has been accessed except (a) a visual inspection of the data of the first 2 participants, to ensure that all data was being stored as expected, and (b) to move data from the lab's local computer to cloud storage, in preparation for analysis. In particular, the data has not been opened or visually inspected by any researcher involved in the analysis of the data. Thus, at the time of this pre-registration, all researchers are "blind" to the collected data. The intention in submitting the current registration is to create and register an analysis plan prior to beginning to process and analyze the data.

Along with basic demographic variables, we will also collect data on infants' productive vocabulary (short form MCDI) and analyze whether vocabulary size correlates with infants' sampling behavior. 

In addition, we will also collect test data to measure infants' learning.
Specifically, we will conduct a 2-alternative forced-choice picture-pointing task testing infants' knowledge of the 8 labels at the conclusion of the experiment.
We have no strong predictions with respect to the test data, but we will conduct exploratory analyses to investigate whether:
1. Infants successfully learn the words.
2. Infants learn more or less frequently labeled objects better.
3. Infants' learning of a particular object-label association is predicted by the frequency with which they sampled that object-label association.
registration_responses.sample: Our target sample size is 50 19- to 21-month-old infants. We conducted a power analysis for our logistic mixed-effects analysis using simulations built with the simr package in R (Green & MacLeod, 2016). We conducted simulations for a range of possible values for our main beta coefficient of interest using random effects and residual variance estimated from a pilot sample of 10 participants, for both of the two main analyses described above (in question 5/Analyses, section (a)). We found that a sample size of 50 participants would provide roughly 80% power to detect an effect of informativeness half of the size (beta=0.4) of that observed in two previous experiments (in which beta ~0.8).
registration_responses.analyses:
Main analyses:
The main analyses will test whether infants' likelihood of selecting novel-object label associations depends on the relative frequency with which two novel object-label associations were experienced during a given training block.

(a) In order to test whether the relative informativeness of object-label associations predicts infants’ sampling choices, our general analytic approach will be to test whether infants’ likelihood of choosing the more informative object-label association increases as the difference in relative frequency increases across the four training conditions. We will fit a logistic mixed-effects model predicting the likelihood of infants’ choosing a given object from the difference in frequency with which that object was labeled compared to the alternative object during the training phase (i.e. from the condition manipulation treated as a continuous predictor). We will include by-participant and by-item random intercepts and a by-participant random slope for condition. The random effects structure will be iteratively pruned until convergence is achieved, removing random effects in order of inferential importance (first removing the random effect for items, then the random slope for condition). We will also fit an analogous model in which we predict infants’ choices from the difference in informativeness of the two object-label association options. Informativeness of each object-label association will be computed as:
informativeness = - log2(relative frequency of object-label), where
relative frequency of object-label = (trials labeling the object)/(total number of training trials)
Note that since log2(0) is not defined, we will set the relative frequency of the object-label association with a frequency of 0 to be half of the lowest possible relative frequency assuming a single labeling event (i.e., 1/16).

(b) In addition to assessing the overall effect of condition, we will also test whether infants show a preference for selecting the more informative object-label association for each block/ condition, using the same logistic mixed-effects modeling approach.

Secondary analyses:
(c) The main analyses will include all sampling trials. To assess the robustness of the results, we will also fit the same models including only the first sampling trial of each block for each participant. In a previous experiment, we observed the strongest effects for the initial sampling trial.
(d) We will conduct secondary analyses using analogously constructed models to test the impact of the frequency manipulation on how long infants fixate the "selected" object during the labeling event in the Sampling Phase. Infants' fixation times will be computed using eye-tracking data collected concurrently with the experiment.
registration_responses.outliers:
Data exclusions:
Infants will be excluded for:
- experimenter error (e.g., if parents were not properly blinded to the experiment with darkened sunglasses or other procedural errors)
- poor or missing calibration (i.e., if fewer than at minimum 3 of the five calibration points are not satisfactorily calibrated for both eyes)
- general infant fussiness during the Training and/ or Sampling Phase.
- Infants must contribute at least one useable gaze-contingent sampling trial in at least two of the four blocks to be included in the analysis.

Trials will be excluded if:
- Sampling trials are not gaze-contingent (i.e., the infant does not trigger the sampling event)
- Poor eye-tracking that impacts the gaze-contingent procedure on a given sampling trial (leading to imprecise timing between infants' fixation and the sampling event)
- infant fussiness during a sampling trial.
- parental interference (e.g., pointing) during a sampling trial.

To assess the robustness of the results to different exclusion criteria, we will also conduct all analyses with a stricter exclusion criterion for sampling trials. In these analyses we will additionally exclude all gaze-contingent sampling trials in which infants required more than 2000 ms to trigger the labeling event, i.e. if infants' fixation triggering the sampling trial is not closely timed with the onset of the sampling opportunity.
registration_responses.dependent: On each sampling trial, infants have the opportunity to trigger one of two objects' label (by fixating a given object). The main dependent measure is which of two object-label associations infants trigger during the Sampling Phase (binary outcome measure). Specifically, infants' sampling choices will be coded in terms of whether they select the object-label association that they experienced less frequently (coded as 1) or more frequently (coded as 0) during training.
registration_responses.conditions: The key manipulation is a within-subjects manipulation of the relative frequency of pairs of object-label associations. The relative frequency of pairs of object-label associations will be varied across four blocks, such that children experience object-label association frequencies of 4:0 (i.e. one object is labeled four times, while the other is never given a label), 4:1, 4:2, and 4:4 in one block each. Thus, while all objects are seen equally often within a given block, the relative frequency with which the two objects are labeled varies across the four blocks of the experiment. The frequency role of the object pairs will be counterbalanced across infants. Each participant views each block/ condition once, in random order.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The overarching goal of the project is to understand how infants seek out new information about words. In particular, do infants sample novel words that are more informative?

In the present study, we ask whether infants' likelihood of selecting novel object-label associations depends on the relative frequency of their experience with these object-label associations.

attributes.title: Flashcard Training with Graphics
attributes.description: This projects analyses the training part of an e-learning study for teaching data programming in R or Python. It is interested in whether the use of graphics accelerates learning.

q1.value: Do faster students spend a greater proportion of time inspecting graphics? Does graphics increase accuracy?

q3.value:
This project involves two studies.

Study 1 involves looking at timestamp data from an e-learning app about data programming in Python/R. The web app consists of a deck of exercise card sets. Each set has three card: a card explaining an operation using a short description and graphic; one card explaining the syntax for how to implement it, and one card with a small interactive exercise. I am wondering whether normalised time duration spent looking at graphic is associated with higher performance (i.e. shorter overall duration).

Study 2: A survey given to the same participants as Study 1, with exercises describing in-context data operations (for example: "Average the ages") with either a graphic or no graphic, and asking participants to place the code for a particular data operation alongside it.

q4.value:
Study 1:
(H1) individual card sets with a high proportion of time spent at graphics are also shorter, when text-length is controlled for
(H2) participants that spend higher proportion of time on graphics are overall faster

Study 2:
(H1) Exercises with graphics are more likely to be correctly answered 
(H2) People with high scores in Study 1 also have more correct answers in Study 2

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: In Study 2, the experimental manipulation is fairly obvious.

question.value:
Study 1 is within-subjects, observational, where each trial corresponds to a card set in the exercise deck and two repeated measurements per trial. There are about 70 sets, but all participants will not have completed all of them due to attrition. Variables are: proportion of time spent on graphic, and absolute time duration on exercise. There is also one quasi-experimental factor of interest: prior programming experience.

Study 2 is a repeated measures experiment with a "graphics" and "no graphics" condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: I am the only person with access to the database, where the data has been securely stored. Although I have inspected the raw data (via MongoDB Compass) to ensure things are being saved correctly, I have never aggregated or visualised the data, in a way that prematurely could reveal trends, effects, or lack thereof.

question.value: I recruited undergraduates and postgraduates at my local institution, from every department. My only exclusion criterion was that they were above 18 years of age. The study lasted from the beginning of February 2020 to beginning of March 2020. There was no payment or other extrinsic motivators, apart from the option to get a handbook containing the content from the course as a PDF.

q13.value: At the time of writing I have blinded myself to the data, so I do not know the attrition rate of the participants. However, the number of participants is in the range of 65-85, with up to 70 unit measurements per participant (1 unit= normalised time on graphic vs. absolute time).

q14.value: The data collection formed part of a larger study that involved a 2x2 within-subjects variable. A priori power analysis had placed the required sample size at about 100 participants. However, this was not reached due to the end of semester (prematurely due to COVID-19) which halted the availability of participants.

q15.value: The initial stopping rule here was reaching the region of 100 participants.

question.value: Study 2: Graphics or not graphics

Study 1:
Time spent looking at graphic (s)
Time spent solving exercise (s)
Length of syntax text on card
Prior programming experience (categorical factor)
I will take the ratio of time spent on graphic over time spent on exercise, as an index for "attention to graphic".

Study 1: 
H1: Multiple regression (Total time ~ Student + Length + Explainer-to-exercise ratio)
H2: Correlation ( explainer-to-exercise ratio, average total time)

Study 2:
H1: Repeated measures t-test
H2: Correlation ( average speed from Study 1, proportion of correct answer )

q20.value: If it is not a bivariate Gaussian distribution, I will use rank-transformation

q22.value: I will exclude cards inspected for more than 10 minutes.

q24.value: I plan on looking, purely descriptively, at visualisations describing the per-trial median durations

attributes.title: Can Bad Be Good? The Attraction of a Darker Self
attributes.description:
Generally, people shy away from similar others with undesirable qualities. We show that when those others are fictional, the opposite occurs. People are drawn toward villains who seem similar to themselves.

The data for all five experiments listed in the paper are presented here.

summary.value: This registration contains the data for Studies 2 and 3 associated with this project, as well as code for reproducing the analyses in the published paper.

registration_responses.summary: This registration contains the data for Studies 2 and 3 associated with this project, as well as code for reproducing the analyses in the published paper.
